# Parametrization of the bifurcated branch {#sec-20230102030224}

$$
\newcommand{\E}{\mathcal{E}}
\newcommand{\order}[2][1]{#2^{(#1)}}
\newcommand{\reals}{\mathbb{R}}
$$

In this chapter, a parametrization of the bifurcated branch is introduced in order to prove Eqs. (@eq-20230528174310),
(@eq-20230411141319), (@eq-20230125062336) and (@eq-20230124205642).

The bifurcated branch is a curve $(u, \lambda) \in \reals ^ {m + 1}$, which is parametrized by $\eta$: $[u(\eta),
\lambda(\eta)]$, with $u(0) = u_0$ and $\lambda(0) = \lambda_0$; primed quantities denoting derivatives with respect to
$\eta$, we introduce
$$
\order[1]{\xi_i} = \xi_i'(0), \quad \order[2]{\xi_i} = \xi_i''(0), \quad \ldots, \quad \order[1]{\lambda} = \lambda'(0), \quad \ldots
$$

In @sec-20230102030125, $\lambda$ was defined as a function of $\xi_1, \ldots, \xi_m$. Therefore, from the chain rule $$
\lambda'(\eta) = \frac{\partial\lambda}{\partial\xi_i} \, \xi_i'(\eta) \quad \text{and} \quad \lambda''(\eta)  = \frac{\partial^2\lambda}{\partial\xi_i \, \partial\xi_j} \, \xi_i'(\eta) \, \xi_j'(\eta) + \frac{\partial\lambda}{\partial\xi_i} \, \xi_i''(\eta)
$$ and, at $\eta = 0$
$$
\order[1]{\lambda} = \lambda_i \, \order[1]{\xi_i} \quad \text{and} \quad \order[2]{\lambda} = \lambda_{ij} \, \order[1]{\xi_i} \, \order[1]{\xi_j} + \lambda_i \, \order[2]{\xi_i}.
$$ {#eq-20230116205753}

## Simplification of the bifurcation equations

The bifurcation equations (@eq-20230115101130) and (@eq-20230115101147) have been derived in @sec-20230102153124.
Testing these equations with $\hat{v} = v_i$ delivers
$$
\xi_j \, \xi_k \, \bigl[ \tfrac{1}{2} \, \E_3(v_i, v_j, v_k) + \lambda_k \, \dot{\E}_2(v_i, v_j) \bigr] = 0
$$ {#eq-20230116205638}
and
$$
\begin{aligned}[b]
\xi_j \, \xi_k \, \xi_l \, \bigl[
\tfrac{1}{2} \E_3(v_i, v_j, w_{kl})
+ \lambda_l \, \E_3(v_i, v_j, w_{k\lambda})
+ \tfrac{1}{6} \E_4(v_i, v_j, v_k, v_l) &\\
+ \tfrac{1}{2} \lambda_l \, \dot{\E}_2(v_i, w_{jk})
+ \lambda_k \, \lambda_l \, \dot{\E}_2(v_i, w_{j\lambda})
+ \tfrac{1}{2} \lambda_{kl} \, \dot{\E}_2(v_i, v_j) &\\
+ \tfrac{1}{2} \lambda_l \, \dot{\E}_3(v_i, v_j, v_k)
+ \tfrac{1}{2} \lambda_k \, \lambda_l \, \ddot{\E}_2(v_i, v_j) \bigr] &= 0.
\end{aligned}
$$ {#eq-20230117071620}
for all $\xi_1, \ldots, \xi_m \in \reals$ and $i = 1, \ldots, m$.

Eq. (@eq-20230116205638) holds for all $\xi_1, \ldots, \xi_m$. Plugging $\xi_i = \order[1]{\xi_i}$ and using
Eq. (@eq-20230116205753) delivers the **first bifurcation equation (@eq-20230125062336)**.

Similarly, Eq. (@eq-20230117071620) is simplified below to the **second bifurcation equation (@eq-20230124205642)**.  To
do so, we first prove a preliminary identity. For fixed $i = 1, \ldots, m$, Eq. (@eq-20230116205638) is of the form
$L_{jk} \, \xi_j \, \xi_k = 0$ for all $\xi_1, \ldots, \xi_m$. Derivation with respect to $\xi_l$ leads to
$$
0 = L_{jk} \, \delta_{jl} \, \xi_k + L_{jk} \, \xi_j \, \delta_{kl} = L_{lk} \, \xi_k + L_{jl} \, \xi_j = \bigl(L_{kl} +L_{lk} \bigr) \, \xi_l,
$$
for all $\xi_1, \ldots, \xi_m \in \reals$. The above identity leads to: $L_{kl} + L_{lk} = 0$. Application to
Eq. (@eq-20230116205638) leads to
$$
E_{ijk} + \lambda_k \, \dot{E}_{ij} + \lambda_j \, \dot{E}_{ik} = 0,
$$ {#eq-20230120210008}

Going back to Eq. (@eq-20230117071620), wich holds for all $\xi_1, \ldots, \xi_m$. Plugging $\xi_i = \order[1]{\xi_i}$
and using Eq. (@eq-20230116205753) delivers
$$
\begin{aligned}[b]
\tfrac{1}{3} \order[1]{\xi}_j \, \order[1]{\xi}_k \, \order[1]{\xi}_l \, \bigl[ \E_4(v_i, v_j, v_k, v_l)
+ 3\E_3(v_i, v_j, w_{kl}) \bigr] &\\
+ \order[1]{\xi}_j \, \order[1]{\xi}_k \, \order[1]{\lambda} \, \bigl[ \dot{\E}_3(v_i, v_j, v_k)
+ 2\E_3(v_i, v_j, w_{k\lambda}) + \dot{\E}_2(v_i, w_{jk}) \bigr] &\\
+ \order[1]{\xi}_j \, \bigl[ \order[1]{\lambda} \bigr]^2 \, \bigl[ 2\dot{\E}_2(v_i, w_{j\lambda})
+ \ddot{\E}_2(v_i, v_j) \bigr]
+ \order[1]{\xi}_j \, \order[1]{\xi}_k \, \order[1]{\xi}_l \, \lambda_{kl} \, \dot{\E}_2(v_i, v_j) &= 0.
\end{aligned}
$$ {#eq-20230124210722}

Owing to the contraction with $\order[1]{\xi}_j$, $\order[1]{\xi}_k$ and $\order[1]{\xi}_l$, the first term can be
symmetrized with respect to $j$, $k$ and $l$
$$
\order[1]{\xi}_j \, \order[1]{\xi}_k \, \order[1]{\xi}_l \, \bigl[ \E_4(v_i, v_j, v_k, v_l) + 3\E_3(v_i, v_j, w_{kl}) \bigr]
= E_{ijkl} \, \order[1]{\xi}_j \, \order[1]{\xi}_k \, \order[1]{\xi}_l,
$$
where $E_{ijkl}$ is defined by Eq. (@eq-20230124210049). Similarly, the second term can be symmetrized with respect to
$j$ and $k$
$$
\begin{aligned}
2 \order[1]{\xi}_j \, \order[1]{\xi}_k \, \E_3(v_i, v_j, w_{k\lambda})
&= \order[1]{\xi}_j \, \order[1]{\xi}_k \, \bigl[ \E_3(v_i, v_j, w_{k\lambda}) + \E_3(v_i, v_k, w_{j\lambda}) \bigr]\\
&= -\order[1]{\xi}_j \, \order[1]{\xi}_k \, \bigl[ \E_2(w_{ij}, w_{k\lambda}) + \E_2(w_{ik}, w_{j\lambda}) \bigr]\\
&= \order[1]{\xi}_j \, \order[1]{\xi}_k \, \bigl[ \dot{\E}_2(v_k, w_{ij}) + \dot{\E}_2(v_j, w_{ik}) \bigr],
\end{aligned}
$$
where we have been testing Eq. (@eq-20230107180410) with $\hat{w} = w_{k\lambda}$ and $\hat{w} = w_{j\lambda}$ and
Eq. (@eq-20230107180501) with $\hat{w} = w_{ij}$ and $\hat{w} = w_{ik}$, successively. Introducing $\dot{E}_{ijk}$
defined by Eq. (@eq-20230124210649), the second term of Eq. (@eq-20230124210722) reduces to
$$
\order[1]{\xi}_j \, \order[1]{\xi}_k \, \order[1]{\lambda} \, \bigl[
\dot{\E}_3(v_i, v_j, v_k) + 2\E_3(v_i, v_j, w_{k\lambda}) + \dot{\E}_2(v_i, w_{jk})
\bigr] = \order[1]{\lambda} \, \dot{E}_{ijk} \, \order[1]{\xi}_j \, \order[1]{\xi}_k.
$$

The third term of Eq. (@eq-20230124210722) is simplified by testing Eq. (@eq-20230107180501), with $\hat{w} = w_{j\lambda}$ and $\hat{w} = w_{i\lambda}$, successively
$$
\begin{aligned}[b]
\ddot{\E}_2(v_i, v_j) + 2\dot{\E}_2(v_i, w_{j\lambda})
&= \ddot{\E}_2(v_i, v_j) + \dot{\E}_2(v_i, w_{j\lambda}) -\E_2(w_{i\lambda}, w_{j\lambda})\\
&= \ddot{\E}_2(v_i, v_j) + \dot{\E}_2(v_i, w_{j\lambda}) + \E_2(v_j, w_{i\lambda})\\
&= \ddot{E}_{ij},
\end{aligned}
$$
where $\ddot{E}_{ij}$ is defined by Eq. (@eq-20230124211207). Gathering the above results delivers the following equation
$$
\begin{aligned}
\tfrac{1}{3} E_{ijkl} \, \order[1]{\xi}_j \, \order[1]{\xi}_k \, \order[1]{\xi}_l
+ \order[1]{\lambda} \, \dot{E}_{ijk} \, \order[1]{\xi}_j \, \order[1]{\xi}_k
+ \bigl[ \order[1]{\lambda} \bigr]^2 \, \ddot{E}_{ij} \, \order[1]{\xi}_j &\\
+ \order[1]{\xi}_j \, \order[1]{\xi}_k \, \order[1]{\xi}_l \, \lambda_{kl} \, \dot{E}_{ij} &= 0.
\end{aligned}
$$

Upon susbtitution of $\order[1]{\xi}_k \, \order[1]{\xi}_l \, \lambda_{kl}$ with
$\order[2]{\lambda} - \lambda_k \, \order[2]{\xi_k}$ \[see Eq. (@eq-20230116205753)\]
$$
\begin{aligned}[b]
\tfrac{1}{3} E_{ijkl} \, \order[1]{\xi}_j \, \order[1]{\xi}_k \, \order[1]{\xi}_l
+ \order[1]{\lambda} \, \dot{E}_{ijk} \, \order[1]{\xi}_j \, \order[1]{\xi}_k
+ \bigl[ \order[1]{\lambda} \bigr]^2 \, \ddot{E}_{ij} \, \order[1]{\xi}_j &\\
+ \order[2]{\lambda} \, \dot{E}_{ij} \, \order[1]{\xi}_j - \order[1]{\xi}_j \, \order[2]{\xi}_k \, \lambda_k \, \dot{E}_{ij} &= 0.
\end{aligned}
$$

Eq. (@eq-20230120210008) is used to eliminate $\lambda_k \, \dot{E}_{ij}$
$$
\begin{aligned}[b]
\tfrac{1}{3} E_{ijkl} \, \order[1]{\xi}_j \, \order[1]{\xi}_k \, \order[1]{\xi}_l
+ \order[1]{\lambda} \, \dot{E}_{ijk} \, \order[1]{\xi}_j \, \order[1]{\xi}_k
+ \bigl[ \order[1]{\lambda} \bigr]^2 \, \ddot{E}_{ij} \, \order[1]{\xi}_j &\\
+ \order[2]{\lambda} \, \dot{E}_{ij} \, \order[1]{\xi}_j
+ \order[1]{\xi}_j \, \order[2]{\xi}_k \, \bigl( E_{ijk} + \lambda_j \, \dot{E}_{ik} \bigr) &= 0
\end{aligned}
$$
and Eq. (@eq-20230124205642) is retrieved.

## Taylor expansion of the bifurcated branch

We now turn to $w$, which was defined in @sec-20230102030010 as an implicit function of $\xi_1, \ldots, \xi_m$ and
$\lambda$. It is now defined as a function of the arc parameter $\eta$ as follows: $w(n) = w[\xi_1(\eta), \ldots, \xi_m(\eta), \lambda(\eta)]$.
From the chain rule
$$
w'(\eta) = \frac{\partial w}{\partial \xi_i} \, \xi_i' + \frac{\partial w}{\partial \lambda} \, \lambda'
$$
and
$$
w''(\eta) = \frac{\partial^2 w}{\partial \xi_i \, \partial \xi_j} \, \xi_i' \, \xi_j'
+ 2\frac{\partial w}{\partial \xi_i \, \partial \lambda} \, \xi_i' \, \lambda'
+ \frac{\partial w}{\partial \xi_i} \, \xi_i''
+ \frac{\partial^2 w}{\partial \lambda^2} \, \lambda^{'2}
+ \frac{\partial w}{\partial \lambda} \, \lambda''.
$$

At $\eta = 0$, the above identities reduce to
$$
w'(0) = 0
\quad \text{and} \quad
w''(0) = \order[1]{\xi_i} \, \order[1]{\xi_j} \, w_{ij}  + 2 \order[1]{\lambda} \, \order[1]{\xi_i} \, w_{i\lambda}
$$

We deduce from the above the Taylor expansion (@eq-20230528174310) of the bifurcated branch as $\eta \to 0$.
